ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lab skills and just going ahead with my project.
I learned a ton from my PI/mentor in lab about my project, the scientific process, etc. but nothing that I had not already been doing as I have worked in my particular lab for almost two years.
I learned how to develop an experiment and work collaboratively with lab members in order to interpret data within the context of a research question.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lab part can only be improved by choosing a good lab to join and having an engaged PI. The actual class part of this course could have been improved if the submission dates and requirements were clearer; there was nowhere to submit the proposal on Canvas, and then an assignment was addd much later, but I had already emailed my proposal, and then I wasn't sure if I should email my final essay or submit it on Canvas. Clarifying this would be ideal.

The one weakness is that the course drastically underestimates how many hours you have to work. There need to be safe guards in order to ensure the well-being of the student. It's not the PI's fault, but someone needs to be like "hey, you don't need to work crazy hours."

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Pretty much the same as normal I'm fairly sure!
I think this course would have operated the same with or without the pandemic. My lab was in-person with capacity limits and social distancing but felt pretty normal.
I did my work in person, so N/A.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Gives you a great amount of time to go to lab, and you get credit for it too!

Take research for credit if you currently work in a lab and want to get a (probably) easy A from it. If you commit to at least 10 hours a week you will get data, even if it is negative data. Make sure you have a good relationship with your PI and your experience will be great; if you worked in their lab over a summer this is even better. If you do these things it will be enjoyable.
Yeah, I think it's a fun way to get to know lab work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Just going into lab separately and independently!
This consists of research for credit performed (in-person for me, at least) in an academic Yale lab - not a teaching lab.
It was like an in-person lab, but it was self-directed.
